Award.AwardTitle: Unitary representations of affine Hecke algebras and reductive p-adic groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project focuses on the study of unitary representations of reductive p-adic groups via affine Hecke algebras. The general approach is motivated by the local Langlands program which predicts a correspondence between the larger class of admissible representations of p-adic groups and certain geometric categories defined in terms of the dual complex group. The first direction of research is the development of an algorithm for computing signatures of invariant hermitian forms for the affine Hecke algebra, motivated by the recent results obtained in the setting of real reductive groups. A second direction concerns basic abstract harmonic analysis problems for (graded) affine Hecke algebras, and certain applications of Dirac operator theory in this setting.

The project falls in the area of representation theory of Lie groups. Lie groups, named after the Norwegian mathematician Sophus Lie, are mathematical objects underlying the symmetries inherent in a system, and their representations, i.e., the ways in which the Lie groups can manifest themselves, have had an important impact in theoretical physics and number theory. This research will generate topics that can constitute bases for Ph.D. or master theses; some problems of combinatorial nature related to the project are suitable for undergraduate research through REU programs.

The Intellectual Merit of the Proposed Activity:

The Principal Investigator (PI) is working in problems within the Langlands Program, proposed by Robert Langlands in 1960s, which is a web of far-reaching and influential conjectures that relate Galois groups in algebraic number theory to automorphic forms and representation theory of algebraic groups over local fields and adeles.

One of the main themes in the theory of automorphic forms and Langlands Program is to study the discrete spectrum of connected reductive groups defined over number fields. For general linear groups, based on the fundamental and general description of residual spectrum due to Langlands, the work of Jacquet, Moeglin and Waldspurger described the explicit construction of the residual spectrum. For classical groups, recently, based on the fundamental work of Ngo, Waldspurger, and many others, Arthur (for symplectic and special orthogonal groups), Mok (for quasi-split unitary groups), and Kaletha, Minguez, Shin and White (for inner forms of unitary groups) classified the discrete spectrum up to automorphic L2-packets parametrized by Arthur parameters. This proves the existence of the endoscopy structure of automorphic forms of quasi-split classical groups that was discovered by Robert Langlands and is part of the Langlands Program.

In global theory, the PI intends to study basic problems towards understanding the structures of those automorphic L2-packets parametrized by Arthur parameters, with applications to number theory and arithmetic geometry.  Explicitly: (1). How to explicitly construct a concrete model for each automorphic representation in any given automorphic L2-packet? (2). How to understand the Fourier coefficients information for the automorphic representations of any given automorphic L2-packet, based on information of the corresponding Arthur parameter? (3). Given any automorphic L2-packet, is it possible to verify whether it contains any cuspidal representation or not? (4). How to understand the relation between automorphic L2-packets of two different but close related groups? In the local theory, the PI intends to study basic problems in harmonic analysis of p-adic groups, in particular, the local converse problems.

One of the major results of the proposal is that, towards Question (3) above, we showed that when considering automorphic forms over totally imaginary number fields, one can give criteria on whether a given automorphic L2-packet contains a cuspidal automorphic form or not, and using this criteria, there are many automorphic L2-packets containing no cuspidal automorphic forms. This result leads to an interesting phenomenon that automorphic forms over totally imaginary number fields and over other number fields behave quite differently, and how to understand this phenomenon is a very interesting research topic in number theory. It worth to mention that one of the main ingredients of this work is the classification of unramified unitary dual of split classical groups by Barbasch, and by Muic-Tadic. Other results include that, we introduced the method of ``twisted automorphic descent", which is a generalization of the famous automorphic descent method developed by Ginzburg, Rallis and Soudry, and has applications, in particular, to the construction of the concrete modules of the cuspidal spectrum of classical groups. 

Another main result of the proposal concerns the local and global converse problems, which aim to recover modular/automorphic forms from their Fourier coefficients, and play important roles on establishing local and global Langlands functoriality transfers. For example, the famous converse theorems of Hecke and Weil give sufficient conditions for a Dirichlet series to be the Mellin transform of a modular form.  We completely proved a long-standing conjecture (since 1980s), called the Jacquet Conjecture on local converse theorem. We also gave a new proof (using purely global method) on the global converse theorem proved by Cogdell and Piatetski-Shapiro, hoping that this new proof would shed some lights on proving the (also long-standing) conjecture on the global converse theorem, which is one of our future projects.


The Broader Impacts Resulting from the Proposed Activity:

The research activities of the PI involves collaborating with D. Jiang in Minnesota, H. Jacquet and M. Adrian in New York, G. Savin in Utah, S. Stevens and P. Xu in UK, C. Jantzen in North Carolina, K. Tam in Canada, B. Xu in China, L. Zhang in Singapore. The PI supported five graduate students in University of Utah, during the summer in 2015, who were working on problems related to the proposal. The PI actively participates on international and national conferences and research workshops in his area. He also gave many seminar and colloquium talks in various universities, including MIT, Brown University, Princeton University, IAS, Duke University, Purdue University, Kansas State University, Rutgers University, UC Berkeley, Louisiana State University, University of Utah, etc.
